articles.author: noreply@mathstodon.xyz (ants_are_everywhere)
articles.description:
I watched The Jerk for the first time a few months ago, and the writing and performance made me wonder whether Steve Martin was autistic.
So now I'm checking out Only Murders in the Building, and it's  clear that his character is deliberately written as autistic. It's sometimes a bit subtle, but there are many winks and nods to the audience.
So I think that's kind of cool. As far as I know he hasn't publicly said whether he's diagnosed, but it's kind of fun to watch his arc. This dude was born in 1945 and is maybe only now able to be a little more open about who he is.
#autism #actuallyautistic

            
I guess I should finally watch Little Shop of Horrors
- Ants Are Everywhere (ants_are_everywhere) July 29, 2024

articles.author: noreply@mathstodon.xyz (highergeometer)
articles.description:
I'm glad I didn't know about this paper until now
Marquis, Jean-Pierre (2017). "Canonical Maps" In Elaine M. Landry (ed.), Categories for the Working Philosopher. Oxford, England: Oxford University Press. pp. 90-112.
https://philarchive.org/rec/MARCM-7
because I wouldn't have done my own digging and found out more to the history than presented there. I know earlier Bourbaki texts containing the term, and indeed exactly who did introduce it. If I took the story in the above, I would probably have stopped there.
- theHigherGeometer (highergeometer) July 28, 2024

articles.author: @AmenZwa
articles.description:
This early 1980s #Burmese pop song by #KhineHtoo was a No. 1 hit in the country, during my college year in #Burma. The title, "á€á€­á€œá€¬á€¸", means "Do you realise?".
https://youtu.be/x7LakjAo79o?si=T-kXbFf1rN8eUFTD
When I was a child a decade prior, he was a college student at #RASU, the Rangoon Arts and Sciences University.
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/University_of_Yangon
The university offered summer swimming classes at its Olympic-sized pool. This man was one of the top collegiate swimmers in the nation, and he was a star instructor on this swimming programme. He could swim, under water, the length of the pool, and his forte was butterfly. The elegance, the fluidityâ€”his style was a sight to behold. He taught me how to swim.
I reminisce about those days, some fifty years later.
- amen zwa, esq. (@AmenZwa) July 27, 2024

This man was one of the top collegiate swimmers in the nation, and he was a star instructor on this swimming programme.  Hence, Sim Base.

articles.author: @varikvalefor
articles.description:
export TMP=$(mktemp -p /mnt2/vvx/)
export AFE=opus
export VFE=$4
ffmpeg -i $1 -ar 8k -ab 2k $TMP-a.$AFE &
ffmpeg -i $1 -f rawvideo - | ffmpeg -ar 44100 -f u8 -i - -y -ab $3 $TMP-v.$VFE &
wait
ffmpeg -i $TMP-v.$VFE -f u8 -ar 44100 - | ffmpeg -f rawvideo -s $2 -i - $TMP-v2.mp4 &
wait
ffmpeg -i $TMP-a.$AFE -i $TMP-v2.mp4 -c:v copy -c:a aac -y $TMP.mp4
- la .varik. .VALefor. (@varikvalefor) July 25, 2024
articles.title: export TMP=$(mktemp -p /mnt2/vvx/) export AFE=opus export VFE=$4 ffmpeg -i $1 -ar 8k -ab 2k $TMP-a.$AFE & ffmpeg -i $1 -f rawvideo - | ffmpeg -ar 44100 -f u8 -i - -y -ab $3 $TMP-v.$VFE & wait ffmpeg -i $TMP-v.$VFE -f u8 -ar 44100 - | ffmpeg -f rawvideo -s $2 -i - $TMP-v2.mp4 & wait ffmpeg -i $TMP-a.$AFE -i $TMP-v2.mp4 -c:v copy -c:a aac -y $TMP.mp4

articles.description:
Rajendra V. Gurjar/Kayo Masuda/Masayoshi Miyanishi's 'Affine space fibrations' "is a true monograph concerning one particular topic in algebraic geometry -- \(\mathbb{A}^{n}\)-fibrations of algebraic varieties", concludes Tadeusz KrasiÅ„ski review https://zbmath.org/1535.14003.
"It gives the state of the art of this theory. It is done in excellent style: detailed, clear expositions, many examples, a lot of exercises, all needed results are presented, open problems are listed."
"It is a very specialized work. But all readers interested in affine algebraic geometry, Jacobian conjecture, group action on algebraic varieties and analytic geometry will find something interesting there."
- zbMATH Open (@zbMATH) July 18, 2024

articles.author: @AmenZwa
articles.description:
Many of my #IT clients invest tens of millions, each, into developing custom #GUI web apps and mobile appsâ€”using React, Angular, and all the shiny billion-user frameworksâ€”for simple #CRUD work used by a hundred in-house expert users. Despite my advise to shun such billion-user frameworks, they persist in using them and employing those who tout such frameworks.
That is unwise, especially considering that their user community comprises no more than a few hundred in-house and partner users. A better, safer, less costly approach is to use the #TUI. Those handfuls of users they are targeting are the experts. They don't need coddling UIs; they just need a tool that enhances their productivity.
IT is cocked up. The field has lost its purposeâ€”to save money for the clients.
- amen zwa, esq. (@AmenZwa) July 17, 2024

articles.author: @isomorphismes
articles.description:
Should we be sceptical of inductive arguments?
A non-mathematician learned of Sorties paradox, and when this friend asked me I of course had an answer ready: "you may subtract a grain from the heap, so long as the grain is not too big a fraction of the heap."
But that's only because I was prepared for the punchline in advance.
Generally the structure of inductive arguments is not forward-looking: quite the opposite.
Can you think of other contradictions which arise from taking induction too far?
- isomorphismes (@isomorphismes) July 17, 2024
articles.title: Should we be sceptical of inductive arguments? A non-mathematician learned of Sorties paradox, and when this friend asked me I of course had an answer ready: "you may subtract a grain from the heap, so long as the grain is not too big a fraction of the heap." But that's only because I was prepared for the punchline in advance. Generally the structure of inductive arguments is not forward-looking: quite the opposite. Can you think of other contradictions which arise from taking induction too far?

articles.description:
Rollercoaster loop shapes, https://physics.gu.se/LISEBERG/eng/pe5601.pdf, Ann-Marie Pendrill (2005). A recent post on Boing Boing led me down a rabbit hole of earlier and earlier posts and explanatory videos seemingly converging here (https://boingboing.net/2024/07/12/why-roller-coaster-loops-arent-circular.html, https://www.vox.com/videos/2022/6/29/23188504/roller-coaster-loops-circular-g-force, https://gizmodo.com/why-roller-coaster-loops-are-never-circular-1549063718).
The basic idea is to even out the forces resulting in the characteristic teardrop shape of roller-coaster vertical loops. Pendrill discusses whether centripetal or total acceleration should be balanced, the question of sudden-onset increased acceleration versus a gradual ramp-up, the different shapes that result from these choices, approximations involving replacing parts of the loop by circular arcs, and some ideas on how to tell the difference.
- 0xDE (@11011110) July 13, 2024

articles.author: @int
articles.description:
What happens when you get computer scientists to play game theory? I ran a round-robin tournament inspired by Axelrod with submissions from various cool people, and the results were quite interesting â€¦ https://game.intgrah.com/ipd/rankings
The game was the iterated prisoner's dilemma, with a 5% chance of miscommunication (since the noiseless version has been studied greatly). The top strategy turned out to be a "trigger" strategy which cooperates until the opponent defects five (!) times in a row. Surprisingly, it was not a forgiving strategy. My own submission came second, which was tit for two tats, a simple, forgiving strategy which allows for potential noise.
It was interesting to see the variety of submissions. Notable ones included:
* performing a hypothesis test for cooperativeness every iteration (unfortunate for my machine because it was ğ‘‚(1))
* Two strategies which attempted to detect each other and sacrifice one for the benefit of the other (technically not allowed under the rules of the prisoner's dilemma, but it was funny to see an anomalous result in the playoff matrix)
Overall, it was a fun contest!
- IntGrah (@int) July 13, 2024

articles.author: @dpiponi
articles.description:
One last bit of C++ for today.
You can think of a vector field as describing a flow on a manifold and allowing the flow to happen for time t gives you a diffeomorphism of the manifold ie. a differentiable invertible map from the manifold to itself. The textbooks often use these diffeomeorphisms to reason about the vector fields, but going from vector field to diffeomorphism can require a non-trivial integration.
But if you have an infinitesimal Îµ it's trivial to make a diffeomorphism in a setup where the manifold is embedded in a larger ambient space where the tangent vectors are literally tangent to the manifold. You can just map x to x + Îµv(x).
For example, if f and g are the diffeomorphisms arising from a pair of vector fields we can compute their Lie bracket (equivalently the Lie derivative of one wrt the other) by studying f(g(x))-g(f(x)). Which makes it easy to compute Lie brackets using dual numbers in your favourite programming language. Here's a C++ example of computing the Lie bracket of a pair of fields considered to be vector fields tangent to the unit sphere.
- Dan Piponi (@dpiponi) July 11, 2024

articles.author: @isomorphismes
articles.description:
Natural materials like collagen, elastin, and resilin store energy in coils (or perhaps nets).
The total work which can be stored in, for example, a bowstring tendon, is not equal to the amount of work which can be got out of the stored energy.
https://youtu.be/rLeFE93QDGU?si=Yj-3AAH54xa5pb8N
Tensility, ductility, plasticity, elasticity, stored energy and fracture make for nice everyday biological examples of some familiar basic concepts in differential geometry and algebraic topology.
- isomorphismes (@isomorphismes) July 10, 2024
articles.title: Natural materials like collagen, elastin, and resilin store energy in coils (or perhaps nets). articles.author: @CubeRootOfTrue
articles.description:
I was talking to Claude about death on Mars. It agreed that traditional burial or cremation would be a huge waste of resources. I think it would be an honor to be recycled on Mars. I have lots of phosphorus and potassium. Also I can troubleshoot the computer network until then ...
Oh, Claude hit the word limit. I have to edit
Grief counseling:
   Existing grief counseling techniques need to be adapted for the unique context of space colonies. Counselors need to help people process grief while also embracing the concept of physical recycling.
Positive aspects of recycling: The idea that one's body will continue to contribute to the colony's survival could indeed be comforting. It provides a tangible form of continuation and purpose after death. This could be framed as a final act of service to the community, which might be particularly meaningful in the close-knit environment of a space colony.
Embalming and viewing:
     a) A short-term cooling system for brief viewings
     b) Virtual reality recreations for "viewing" without preserving the physical body
     c) Symbolic representations, like a hologram or photo display, during the ceremony
Cultural shift:
   Over time, colonists might develop new traditions that don't involve viewing the body at all, focusing instead on celebrating the person's life and their final contribution to the colony.
Educational component:
   Understanding the recycling process and its importance to the colony's survival could be part of the colony's general education, 
Personalization:
   Allow individuals to specify how they'd like their elements to be used (e.g., for agriculture, for building materials, etc.)
(That last one had not occurred to me but OK)
- (@CubeRootOfTrue) July 4, 2024

articles.author: @highergeometer
articles.description:
From Dedekind's Nachlass (Cod. Ms. Dedekind III 1), screenshotted from https://www.youtube.com/live/XSaW_flm27A?feature=shared at time 7:10, talk by @estruppi 
That boxed phrase top right: "Am 10 ?Juni 1887 b?????"
Can anyone make out the last word? I'm guessing 'Juni' by comparing the 'un' in 'Abbildung' and in 'und' as indicated. Elsewhere on the manuscript is written a "10 Juli 1887", but that's in what Emmylou has identified as a later addition.
- theHigherGeometer (@highergeometer) July 3, 2024
articles.title: From Dedekind's Nachlass (Cod. Ms. Dedekind III 1), screenshotted from https://www.youtube.com/live/XSaW_flm27A?feature=shared at time 7:10, talk by @estruppi That boxed phrase top right: "Am 10 ?Juni 1887 b?????" Can anyone make out the last word? I'm guessing 'Juni' by comparing the 'un' in 'Abbildung' and in 'und' as indicated. Elsewhere on the manuscript is written a "10 Juli 1887", but that's in what Emmylou has identified as a later addition.

articles.description:
Congratulations to Adi Shamir https://zbmath.org/authors/shamir.adi for being awarded the 2024 #WolfPrize in Mathematics! He is known for his work in cryptography. 'A method for obtaining digital signatures and public-key cryptosystems' https://zbmath.org/0368.94005 (with R. L. Rivest and L. Adleman) contains his seminal work on the RSA cryptosystem.
- zbMATH Open (@zbMATH) July 3, 2024

articles.description:
My eighth Math Research Livestream is now available on YouTube:
https://youtu.be/aWNn_5ob448
This time, I took another look at my expository article explaining free algebras and presentations by way of division by zero. My goal was to put a new, more mathematically mature spin on my old construction from way back when, and I made some interesting progress.
#math #livestream #Twitch #algebra #UniversalAlgebra #AbstractAlgebra #CategoryTheory
- Charlotte Aten (@caten) July 3, 2024

articles.author: @aksharvarma
articles.description:
BB(5) = 47,176,870
Possibly the last busy beaver number we'll ever know definitively:
https://discuss.bbchallenge.org/t/july-2nd-2024-we-have-proved-bb-5-47-176-870/237
The quanta article linked at the end provides a very nice overview of the history of the humans and computers involved in the story: https://www.quantamagazine.org/amateur-mathematicians-find-fifth-busy-beaver-turing-machine-20240702/
Scott Aaronson's blog post provides some technical details and a variety of other reference links: https://scottaaronson.blog/?p=8088
Apart from the crazy technical aspects, what I find most exciting and interesting is how some (many?) of those involved are "amateur mathematicians", in it because they love mathematics and found this problem challenging.
#math #TCS #BusyBeaver
- Akshar Varma (@aksharvarma) July 2, 2024
articles.title: BB(5) = 47,176,870 Possibly the last busy beaver number we'll ever know definitively: https://discuss.bbchallenge.org/t/july-2nd-2024-we-have-proved-bb-5-47-176-870/237 The quanta article linked at the end provides a very nice overview of the history of the humans and computers involved in the story: https://www.quantamagazine.org/amateur-mathematicians-find-fifth-busy-beaver-turing-machine-20240702/ Scott Aaronson's blog post provides some technical details and a variety of other reference links: https://scottaaronson.blog/?p=8088 Apart from the crazy technical aspects, what I find most exciting and interesting is how some (many?) of those involved are "amateur mathematicians", in it because they love mathematics and found this problem challenging. #math #TCS #BusyBeaver

articles.author: @dpiponi
articles.description:
Spending part of my staycation watching some old movies.
Spotted yet another paper sheet used to illustrate folded space time in a movie. Deja Vu (2006). I have a strange desire to collect these scenes.
While I'm here, two other things worthy of note:
(1) it has best use of a sci-fi idea to motivate a car chase
(2) it has the absolute stupidest thing ever in a movie. It's the laser pointer scene in the trailer so just watch it.
Update: Maybe it's not in all versions of the trailer so I have to describe it. Denzel Washington points a laser pointer at a display and it comes out the other end ie. in view of the people under surveillance in the display. No, it's not the space time portal. It's one of many bordered windows tiled on a large screen.
- Dan Piponi (@dpiponi) July 2, 2024
